Boston.com
10

In Ecuador, Guaman gets 25 years for Brockton murders

An Ecuadoran court has sentenced Luis Guaman to the maximum penalty for the 2011 beating deaths of a young mother and her 2-year-old son. (Globe, 11:46 a.m.)
  • 4/30 Luis Guaman convicted for Brockton double-murder

Red Sox: Keep or trade him?

With the Red Sox struggling, is it time to put some players on the trading block?

Pictures: Patriots cheerleader boot camp

It's not all glitz and glamour for the Patriots cheerleaders, who must attend a rigorous two-week, four-session boot camp if they hope to make the squad.
  • Story: Patriots cheerleaders must pass boot camp
  • Pictures Patriots cheerleader tryouts | 2011 tryouts

New England Mafia racked by arrests

The New England Mafia is a skeleton of the organization it once was. Younger members are addicted to drugs, and the older members have either died or gone to jail. (Globe)
  • Discuss Your thoughts on this article

Facebook brings its IPO pitch to Boston

Mark Zuckerberg was a no-show today as Facebook executives sought to woo potential investors ahead of its initial public stock offering. (Globe, 12:02 p.m.)

With unemployment still above 8 percent, the money swilling around the bizarre system of exchange we call the art market is incongruous, to say the least.

Charter school cap lifted by the state

Officials will lift a temporary moratorium on proposals to open charter schools in several cities, a move that could create more than 1,000 seats in Boston.
Opinion | Farah Stockman

Boston vs. The Big Easy

Unlike Boston, New Orleans prides itself on unabashed displays of friendliness.

A home for dance in Cambridge

Green Street Studios, which will hold a 20th anniversary gala benefit performance on Saturday, has created a strong, creative dance community.

The former chief executive of Sovereign Bancorp is back yet again, taking another bank built from scratch to the public stock market.

Painted ads resurface in NYC

New York is sprinkled with barely visible old ads painted on the sides of buildings -- remnants of lost eras of urban life. Now, they're making a comeback as a nostalgic art form.
